awd_titl_txt: FW-HTF-RL: Collaborative Research: Enabling Marginalized Rural and Urban Digital Workers to Collaborate with AI to Learn Skills, Increase Wages, and Access Creative Work
awd_abstract_narration:
Many rural areas in the United States face a lack of economic opportunity. The future of work can bring opportunities for rural and urban marginalized communities through online work and the gig economy. However, work on current platforms is often low-level labeling work offering few opportunities for advancement. It is often intended to train Artificial Intelligence to automate this work away, instead of training workers. The proposed project aims to uplift workers and improve the marketplace for online work so that digital work may help with the economic recovery of regions whose traditional industries have left. This project aims to develop sustainable methods for transitioning workers to high-skilled and creative digital jobs that are unlikely to be automated in the near to medium term future. Crowd work can be transformed to not only improve the work product for the employer, but also to help the worker move along the career paths necessary for the future of work. The project team from four universities, Carnegie Mellon U., West Virginia U., Pennsylvania State University and University of Pennsylvania has partnered with local institutions to provide workers training to perform progressively more advanced digital work, while earning money. The vision of the project is to scaffold workers through basic computer fluency, working with AI tools, and finally innovation and creativity skills. This work is in collaboration with a rural partner (Rupert Public Library, in Rupert, WV) and urban partner (CommunityForge in Wilkinsburg, PA) and also benefits from a partnership with Bosch Inc. in Pittsburgh, ConservationX Labs in Washington DC, and the State of West Virginia.

The proposed research addresses a fundamental challenge in that those who most need to develop skills to gain higher paying jobs cannot afford the unpaid time spent in training needed to develop them. Accomplishing this vision will require solving the following core research questions: (i) How can one best support the marginalized workers in their transition to online work?, (ii) How can Artificial Intelliegnce tools augment workers, rather than displace them?, (iii) How can tools be designed to help workers build skills and creativity for work that is unlikely to be automated in the future?.  This project has the potential to make advances across a variety of interrelated fields including crowdsourcing, Artificial Intelligence, Human Computer Interaction, Cognitive Science, Learning Science, Sociology and Economics. Simultaneously enabling both improved work outcomes as well as skill development in crowd work will require the development of models of workers, skills, and their trajectories at a more nuanced level. Enabling workers to collaborate with Artificial Intelligence will require new human-computer interaction paradigms. Supporting creativity and the development of new skills will require the exploration of new organization and coordination structures. By grounding the investigations in real world contexts, the research aims for generalizable knowledge that can lay a foundation for research on the future of crowd work at the human-AI frontier

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project aims to develop sustainable methods for transitioning workers to high-skilled and creative digital jobs that are unlikely to be automated in the near to medium term future. The key novel insight is that existing paid work opportunities in crowd work can be transformed to not only improve the work product for the employer, but also to help the worker move along the career paths necessary for the future of work. We address a fundamental challenge in that those who most need to develop skills to gain higher paying jobs cannot afford the time to take off working to develop them.

 Accomplishing this vision requires addressing the following core research questions: (i) How can we best support the marginalized workers in their transition to online work?, (ii) How can AI tools augment workers, rather than displace them?, (iii) How can we design tools to help workers build skills for work that is unlikely to be automated in the future? In this project, we partner with local institutions to provide workers training to perform progressively more advanced digital work, while earning money.

Our vision is to scaffold workers through basic computer fluency, working with AI tools, and finally innovation and entrepreneurship skills. Our initial goal was to establish ourselves in the communities of interest with our partners' assistance, both in the rural context in a library in rural West Virginia and in the urban context in Pittsburgh's Community Forge. From this participation, we planned to develop insight into the design of tools and processes that would be truly useful to these populations. Over the subsequent years of the project, we have leveraged this community buy-in to conduct deep work with the communities involved, while also innovating in areas related to Human-AI collaboration relevant for work that are further out.

Generative AI systems like ChatGPT had a breakthrough moment during the last two years of the grant period, with widespread public usage and debate. This class of AI has the potential to greatly increase worker productivity and unlock new forms of creativity. However, there is still high uncertainty around the impact generative AI will have on the future of work. On one hand, it could augment human capabilities, helping workers generate art, enhancing writing, and allowing programmers to code more efficiently. But on the other hand, the automation of tasks previously thought to require advanced skills could displace many white-collar office jobs. As researchers exploring the human-technology frontier, we must carefully study both the benefits and risks of these emerging technologies. Our goal  is to develop AI tools that empower workers rather than replace them, ensuring these innovations improve livelihoods and increase opportunities. With thoughtful design and policy, generative AI could positively transform work while avoiding potential pitfalls.  In addition to our own research, we have used our expertise to communicate with policymakers –including the copyright office and congress– about the implications of generative AI.

During the past year, we have conducted workshops with entrepreneurs with our community partners, and have used these both to improve our understanding of how people use these tools, and also used insights from the workshops to guide our on-going technical systems design. In one project, for instance, we are looking to scaffold entrepreneurs through using large language models to write business plans. While LLMs can produce something that looks like a business plan, understanding the content and having it represent the actual needs of the business owner is at least as difficult. We believe this is a generalizable trend, where complex work needs specific design work to support use cases that matter, and so we hope to learn and share more about our work in supporting this.

At the same time, business owners are increasingly using generative AI to help them in their processes. In another thread of work, we are exploring how they are using this technology and how it influences the production of job ads in particular, which are an important conduit between employers and potential workers.

To train students, our team has also helped to launch two new AI degrees – one undergraduate AI degree (the first of its kind at an Ivy League institution), and one online AI master’s degree.  As part of our course development, we also created a free Coursera specialization called “AI and Machine Learning Essentials with Python”.
